description: For each question, select the answer that most accurately describes your organization's current state. Each answer choice corresponds to a maturity level, from 1 (lowest) to 5 (highest). After completing the five questions for a pillar, calculate the average score for that pillar to determine your organization's approximate maturity level in that area.

pillars.name: Ethical, Equitable, & Responsible Use
pillars.description: This pillar assesses how your organization establishes expectations and governance to mitigate the risks and unintended consequences of AI initiatives.

questions.question: How does your organization ensure AI systems are governable and that there is a process for accountability?

A.text: No formal governance process is in place for AI accountability.

B.text: We are in the process of defining governance and enforcement approaches for accountable AI.

C.text: Responsible use governance and compliance practices are in place for accountable and contestable AI solutions.

D.text: Responsible AI use is widespread, with governance and enforcement practices in place for monitoring and reporting.

E.text: Our accountability and governance approaches are continuously improved based on data and trend analysis.

questions.question: To what degree are your AI systems' decisions transparent and explainable to users and those impacted?

A.text: No standardized approach exists to enable traceability or explainability for AI outputs.

B.text: A standardized methodology to trace, explain, and make AI solutions transparent is in process.

C.text: An approved and utilized approach is in place to trace, explain, and justify outputs and outcomes for AI solutions.

D.text: Enterprise-based approaches that enforce transparency and justification of AI outcomes exist, with compliance audits and checks monitored and measured.

E.text: Our enterprise-based approaches for transparency are routinely utilized and improved through data-trend analysis and performance improvement.

questions.question: How does your organization address potential bias and ensure AI systems are fair and equitable?

A.text: There are no clear policies or standards to ensure fairness, respect human rights, or avoid bias in AI.

B.text: AI policies and standards that ensure fairness and equitability are currently being considered.

C.text: An approved set of AI policies, standards, and approaches that ensure fairness and equitability are defined, documented, and approved.

D.text: Enterprise-based policies ensuring ethical practices and fairness are monitored, measured, and reported using qualitative metrics.

E.text: Our policies and standards for fairness and ethics are optimized using data-trend analysis and performance improvement based on human rights assessments.

questions.question: What process exists for individuals to challenge or appeal an AI-driven decision that affects them?

A.text: There is no process for contesting or appealing AI-driven findings.

B.text: We are currently designing a process that will allow for challenges to AI outcomes.

C.text: A formal, documented, and timely process for contesting AI solution outcomes is in place.

D.text: The contestation process is widely used and monitored, and it is integrated with our overall governance and enforcement practices.

E.text: Insights gathered from the appeals process are systematically used to improve the fairness and governability of our AI systems enterprise-wide.

questions.question: How are human rights and diversity considered in the design of your AI systems?

A.text: Human rights and diversity are not formally considered in the AI design process.

B.text: Respect for human rights and diversity is being considered as part of emerging AI policies.

C.text: AI systems are designed with deliberate steps to accommodate human rights and diversity to avoid unfair consequences, as defined in approved policies.

D.text: Adherence to human rights assessments of fairness and equitability is monitored and measured across the enterprise.

E.text: Human-centric design is deeply embedded, and our approaches are optimized using data-trend analysis and performance improvement cycles.

pillars.name: Strategy & Resources
pillars.description: This pillar assesses the availability of strategic plans, a governance model, and the necessary resources for AI solutions.

questions.question: What is the status of your organization's AI strategic plan?

A.text: No enterprise-based AI mission, vision statement, policies, or budget is present.

B.text: An AI mission/vision statement, policies, leadership roles, and budget are being defined.

C.text: An approved AI mission/vision statement, leadership roles, and budget are in place and achieving defined objectives.

D.text: An AI mission/vision strategy is articulated, leadership is engaged, and the monitoring of outcomes and objectives occurs.

E.text: The AI strategy, policies, and standards are continually reviewed, modified, and updated to improve organizational outcomes and capabilities.

questions.question: How are resources, such as funding and personnel, allocated to AI initiatives?

A.text: Funding is ad-hoc, and there is no designated AI sponsor or champion to mature AI capabilities.

B.text: A budget is being defined for AI, and champions are being established to support initiatives.

C.text: AI projects are aligned with enterprise-wide plans and are allocated resources based on approved performance outcomes.

D.text: Leadership makes decisions on resource allocation by analyzing data against defined metrics to determine enterprise-wide impact.

E.text: Resource allocation is strategically optimized by breaking down silos to integrate resources effectively and realize enhanced AI across the enterprise.

questions.question: How is AI governance structured and executed in your organization?

A.text: No AI governance structure, audits, processes, or standards are in place.

B.text: AI governance and processes to guide how AI is developed and used are being initiated.

C.text: AI governance and processes are established, accountable executives are identified, and audits are in place and utilized.

D.text: AI governance is routinely carried out with representative participation, and metrics are consistently collected to inform adherence to standards.

E.text: AI governance is actively engaged in improving AI solution development by re-evaluating and optimizing existing standards, processes, and policies.

questions.question: How does your organization leverage external partnerships for AI innovation?

A.text: No AI partnerships with industry, academia, or other agencies exist.

B.text: AI partnerships with industry, academia, or other agencies are being formed.

C.text: AI partnerships are in place, and ethical, responsible-use practices are included in partnership agreements.

D.text: Information from academic, industry, and agency partnerships is being applied to inform and enhance AI initiatives.

E.text: There is a proactive process in place for identifying, initiating, and executing new collaborative partnerships to continuously improve AI initiatives.

questions.question: How visible is leadership's sponsorship and support for AI initiatives?

A.text: AI efforts lack senior management leadership, and no AI sponsor is designated.

B.text: Executive support is evident through initial funding, but it lacks visible sponsorship and championship.

C.text: Senior leadership and AI sponsors take an active role in sponsoring change through a formal, company-wide program.

D.text: Leadership is actively making decisions by analyzing data against defined metrics to determine enterprise-wide impact.

E.text: Effective AI is an explicitly stated strategic goal, and executives have made it a priority, serving as champions for adoption.

pillars.name: Organization
pillars.description: This pillar assesses if the organization's culture, structure, and workforce development can enable effective AI solutions.

questions.question: How would you describe the organization's culture regarding AI adoption and risk tolerance?

A.text: The organizational culture does not support widespread acceptance and use of AI.

B.text: An evaluation of the organization's culture and the changes needed for AI adoption is occurring.

C.text: Cultural changes necessary for successful AI adoption are identified, and an implementation strategy is being executed.

D.text: Acceptance of AI use is widespread, and cultural changes are monitored, measured, and analyzed.

E.text: The organization accepts and embraces AI on an enterprise-wide basis, and the culture is adaptive, action-oriented, and supports responsible, innovative AI.

questions.question: How are AI-related roles, responsibilities, and teams formally structured?

A.text: The organization does not have AI-specific structures, roles, and processes defined or documented.

B.text: Enterprise-based AI structures are rudimentary but functional; roles are present but limited in definition.

C.text: AI structures, roles, and processes are defined for the entity, which may include the co-design of an AI Center of Excellence (CoE).

D.text: Enterprise-based AI structures, roles, and processes are enabled, and resources are applied to monitor and measure performance.

E.text: Enterprise-based AI structures are defined, documented, and measured, with metrics utilized to improve activities and implement best practices.

questions.question: What is your organization's approach to AI workforce development and training?

A.text: No workforce plan is in place for AI development, and there is insufficient training.

B.text: An AI workforce development plan is in process, and foundational literacy training is being delivered.

C.text: An AI workforce development plan is in place and implemented to meet resource needs, including workshops and certifications.

D.text: The AI workforce plan is meeting expectations and capturing metrics to define current and future needs, with dedicated positions supporting AI competence.

E.text: The workforce plan is continuously improved using metrics, and a culture of continuous learning with advanced training and mentorship is established.

questions.question: How effective is cross-functional collaboration on AI projects between different business units?

A.text: AI projects are isolated, information is not centralized, and there is no common approach.

B.text: Different approaches are applied sporadically throughout the organization; there is no common methodology.

C.text: Standardized AI requirements and approaches are used by multiple projects.

D.text: Multiple projects exist that utilize standard technologies and approaches, and teams capture metrics and best practices to achieve strategic outcomes.

E.text: The organization has broken down silos to integrate data and resources effectively, realizing enhanced AI across the enterprise.

questions.question: What is the level of AI literacy and fluency across the organization?

A.text: Project teams and leaders have little or no information about AI.

B.text: Foundational AI literacy training and an introduction to AI concepts are being delivered.

C.text: A common understanding of AI terminology, concepts, and applications has been achieved, enabling informed discussions.

D.text: There is enterprise-wide training and acknowledgement of AI and the importance of following defined standards for project success.

E.text: AI maturity and competency is a common skill set, and employees across the enterprise understand AI and their role in making it successful.

pillars.name: Technology Enablers
pillars.description: This pillar assesses the establishment of technology enablers, including innovation, testing, and infrastructure, to produce AI solutions.

questions.question: How does your organization provide and manage AI platforms and infrastructure?

A.text: No AI-specific platform, processes, or tools are available.

B.text: AI-specific platforms and tools are being identified and acquired to support initiatives.

C.text: AI-specific platforms, tools, and processes are available to support initiatives and projects.

D.text: AI-optimized platforms are routinely monitored to capture performance data and support technology refreshment.

E.text: AI-optimized platforms are used for initiatives and are enhanced by performance data.

questions.question: What is your process for the Test and Evaluation (T&E) of AI models?

A.text: No guidelines for AI-specific T&E exist; solutions are tested using traditional software approaches.

B.text: AI-specific T&E techniques like basic model debugging and bias validation are being utilized.

C.text: AI-specialized test approaches, such as data sensitivity and discrimination testing, are defined and standardized.

D.text: AI T&E standards are integrated into acquisition and operations processes, and test results are audited to ensure solutions meet quality targets.

E.text: AI T&E standards and processes are enterprise-based, and improvement through continual testing and trend analysis is facilitating product outcomes.

questions.question: How does your organization foster and integrate AI innovation into business operations?

A.text: No defined approach is present to research, identify, and utilize AI-specific systems engineering or human-machine practices.

B.text: An approach to AI-specific systems engineering and human-machine practices is being developed.

C.text: An approved approach to AI-specific systems engineering and human-machine practices is in place and communicated.

D.text: The approved approach is widespread, and metrics are collected and analyzed to measure effectiveness.

E.text: The approach to AI-specific systems engineering and human-machine practices is being refined to better achieve alignment with enterprise objectives.

questions.question: To what extent has your organization adopted MLOps (Machine Learning Operations) practices?

A.text: MLOps practices are non-existent; model deployment is manual and ad-hoc.

B.text: We are beginning to explore introductory MLOps principles for pilot projects.

C.text: We are launching impactful pilot projects with defined MLOps principles for solution scoping and deployment.

D.text: We have implemented robust and mature MLOps practices as part of a scalable, enterprise-wide strategy.

E.text: Our MLOps framework is a core driver of business innovation, continuously optimized for operational excellence and competitive advantage.

questions.question: How is security integrated into the AI/ML development lifecycle (e.g., Secure-by-Design)?

A.text: Security is not considered during the design phase of AI/ML pipelines.

B.text: Security is considered on an ad-hoc basis but is not a formal part of the design or development process.

C.text: We provide expert guidance on embedding security at the design phase, covering AI/ML pipelines and supply chain integrity.

D.text: Comprehensive maturity assessments include adversarial risk evaluation and system assurance aligned with NIST AI RMF and DoD cyber standards.

E.text: End-to-end lifecycle risk mitigation is embedded and continuously optimized in all AI development, serving as a model for operational excellence.

pillars.name: Data
pillars.description: This pillar assesses if AI initiatives have the needed data—available, accessible, and secure—for successful implementation.

questions.question: How does your organization govern data used for AI to ensure its quality, usability, and integrity?

A.text: No AI data governance process or entity is in place.

B.text: An initial AI data governance entity or framework is being defined.

C.text: An approved AI data governance entity/framework is in place, and initial audits may be performed.

D.text: An enterprise-wide AI data governance entity/framework is utilized with audits and monitoring, supported by metrics.

E.text: The enterprise-wide AI data governance framework is utilized with metrics and monitoring to improve data performance and compliance over time.

questions.question: Describe your organization's data architecture for supporting AI.

A.text: No common AI data architecture or framework is in place.

B.text: An initial AI data architecture/framework is being developed.

C.text: An approved enterprise-wide data architecture is consistent with the AI implementation plan and the needs of AI initiatives.

D.text: An enterprise-wide data architecture/framework is implemented, consistently utilized, and monitored.

E.text: An optimized common data architecture is utilized across the enterprise and is updated to meet the evolving needs of AI initiatives.

questions.question: How accessible is data for AI teams, and how is data sharing managed?

A.text: Data is siloed, and no data-sharing service framework or agreement is in place.

B.text: A data-sharing framework is in process to provide common data-sharing agreements and facilitate data cataloging.

C.text: An approved data-sharing framework and agreements are in place that provide the data availability and accessibility needed to support AI.

D.text: A data-sharing framework and agreements are routinely used and verified by metrics to support consistency in data usage.

E.text: Enterprise-wide data-sharing service framework and agreements are improved from collected data analytics and best practices.

questions.question: How are data security and privacy protected in your AI systems?

A.text: No AI-specific privacy and data security rights, approaches, or standards are in place.

B.text: AI-specific privacy and data-security rights, approaches, and standards are being developed.

C.text: AI-specific privacy and data security rights, approaches, and standards are defined and approved.

D.text: Enterprise-wide, AI-specific privacy and data security rights, approaches, and standards are managed and monitored.

E.text: Enterprise-wide, AI-specific privacy and data security rights and standards are improved and optimized based upon data trends.

questions.question: How does your organization determine if data is ready and appropriate for an AI use case?

A.text: Data readiness is not formally evaluated; data is used as-is.

B.text: Data readiness is discussed informally for some projects, focusing on availability.

C.text: Data readiness is evaluated as part of early-fit identification, but the process is not yet standardized.

D.text: We have a standard, data-driven process for assessing data readiness, quality, and feasibility for all potential AI projects.

E.text: We have a proactive and automated capability to assess, track, and improve data readiness across the enterprise for future AI needs.

pillars.name: Performance & Application
pillars.description: This pillar assesses the effective development, deployment, operation, and maintenance of AI-enabled capabilities.

questions.question: How are AI solutions integrated into business workflows and adopted by users?

A.text: No AI business use cases are identified or documented, and solutions are not linked to workflows.

B.text: AI business use cases are being developed and documented, and integrated solutions are being aligned to workflows.

C.text: An approved set of AI business use cases are in place, integrated solutions are aligned to workflows, and strategic outcomes are being formulated.

D.text: Enterprise-based AI business use cases are linked to solutions and are quantified by specific key performance indicators (KPIs) that measure strategic outcomes.

E.text: Enterprise-based AI business use cases and solutions are routinely assessed and evaluated by KPIs to inform outcomes and improve future strategic goals.

questions.question: How are deployed AI solutions monitored for changes in performance, fairness, or security over time?

A.text: No systematic approach and process are available for monitoring post-deployment AI performance.

B.text: AI solution-specific monitoring techniques, such as for model decay or fairness, are in process of being developed.

C.text: A systematic approach and process for monitoring, evaluating, and responding are defined to monitor AI system outputs.

D.text: Post-deployment AI initiatives are monitoring results and using performance anomaly results to direct corrective actions to improve outcomes.

E.text: Data from post-deployment AI performance anomalies are collected and support continuous improvements of enterprise-wide monitoring activities.

questions.question: How do you ensure that your AI systems are robust and reliable in operation?

A.text: No AI-specific robustness and reliability standards or approaches are in place.

B.text: AI-specific reliability and robustness approaches and models are being evaluated and tested for viability.

C.text: Tested and defined approaches for assuring robust and reliable AI solutions are available and utilized.

D.text: Post-deployment monitoring results and performance anomaly data are used to direct corrective actions to improve outcomes.

E.text: Data from post-deployment performance anomalies are collected and support continuous improvements of enterprise-wide monitoring and reliability activities.

questions.question: How does your organization build and maintain user trust in its AI systems?

A.text: No systematic due diligence processes or standards are in place to measure and calibrate user trust.

B.text: Due diligence processes, techniques, and standards are being developed to measure trust and enable stakeholder communication.

C.text: Due diligence processes and communication mechanisms are defined and approved to measure trust and correct miscalibrations.

D.text: Due diligence processes are present at an enterprise level, and AI initiatives are actively monitoring trust metrics.

E.text: Due diligence processes, techniques, and standards are being improved based on quantitative analysis of incidents.

questions.question: How do you measure the business value or Return on Investment (ROI) of your AI initiatives?

A.text: ROI is not measured or considered for AI projects.

B.text: ROI is discussed informally for some pilot projects but is not formally calculated.

C.text: We conduct documented ROI analysis for key pilot projects and document learnings.

D.text: We have a standardized process to collect metrics and determine the impact and business value of AI initiatives across the enterprise.

E.text: ROI and value metrics are continuously tracked and used to dynamically optimize the AI investment portfolio for maximum strategic impact.
